1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Viral gastroenteritis due to Rotavirus; Prophylaxis: As of May 14, 2010, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recommended that clinicians continue use of the RotaTeq(R) vaccine despite the presence of porcine circovirus type-1 DNA (PCV1) and type-2 DNA (PCV2) in the vaccine, as there is no evidence of a safety risk
  • Viral gastroenteritis due to Rotavirus; Prophylaxis: RotaTeq(R), 2 mL (entire pouch) ORALLY at 6 to 12 weeks of age, second and third dose at 4- to 10-week intervals; third dose should not be given after 32 weeks of age (manufacturer dosing) OR 3-dose series at age 2, 4, and 6 months (guideline dosing)

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Viral gastroenteritis due to Rotavirus; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• intussusception, history of
  • severe allergic reaction (eg, anaphylaxis) after a previous dose or to a vaccine component (CDC); hypersensitivity to any component of the vaccine (manufacturer)
  • Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Disease (SCID)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • bladder exstrophy
  • gastrointestinal disorders, history of (chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive, congenital abdominal disorders, abdominal surgery, or active acute gastrointestinal illness); no safety and efficacy data
  • immunocompromised infants (malignancies, HIV/AIDS, cellular immune deficiencies, hypo- or dysgammaglobulinemia, or receiving immunosuppressive therapy); no safety and efficacy data
  • infants who received blood transfusion, blood products, including immunoglobulins, within 42 days; no safety or efficacy data
  • infants with blood dyscrasias, leukemia, lymphomas, or other malignant neoplasms affecting bone marrow or lymphatic system; no safety or efficacy data
  • recipients who have close contacts to individuals with immunodeficiencies (malignancies, primary immunodeficiency, immunocompromised, or receiving immunosuppressive therapy); transmission of vaccine virus strains from vaccinees to non-vaccinated contacts has been reported
  • spina bifida
  • report any adverse events through the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono:
• Rotavirus Vaccine, Live: C (FDA)
  • Rotavirus Vaccine, Live: B2 (AUS)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Rotavirus Vaccine, Live: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

sub.mono:

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (6.1% to 10.4%), Vomiting (3.6% to 6.7%)
  • Otic:Otitis media (14.5%)
  • Psychiatric:Irritability (2.9% to 8.1%)
  • Respiratory:Bronchospasm (1.1%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastroenteritis (0.2%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Severe combined immunodeficiency disease
  • Neurologic:Seizure (less than 0.1%)
  • Other:Angioedema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The rotavirus live pentavalent vaccine (Rotateq(R) contains 5 live reassortant rotaviruses, with rotavirus parent strains of the reassortants isolated from human and bovine hosts. Although the exact mechanism of pentavalent live rotavirus vaccine is unclear, it contains a live, attenuated human rotavirus that replicates in the small intestine and induces immunity against gastroenteritis.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • may be administered with food and liquid, including breast milk, either before or after vaccination
  • if infant regurgitates, spits out, or vomits during or after administration, it is not recommended to readminister the dose; remaining recommended doses should be given at the appropriate intervals
  • do not mix with any other vaccines or solution
  • do not reconstitute or dilute
  • administer as soon as possible after removal from refrigeration

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause diarrhea or vomiting.
  • Advise patient to call healthcare professional if a treatment is missed, as drug should be given on a fixed schedule.
